name: .NET Goat
author: OWASP
notes: Original main repo: https://github.com/jerryhoff/WebGoat.NET. Others: https://github.com/rapPayne/WebGoat.Net , https://github.com/jowasp/WebGoat.NET.

name: AI-Goat
author: fhammon, Guanwei Hu
notes: AI Goat uses the Vicuna LLM which derived from Meta's LLaMA and coupled with ChatGPT's response data. When installing AI Goat the LLM binary is downloaded from third party locally on your computer.

name: AWS CTF Challenge
author: AWS Security Team
notes: Capture-the-flag challenges for AWS

name: AWS Infrastructure Pentest Lab
author: AWS Security Team
notes: Hands-on lab for AWS infrastructure pentesting

name: AWS Security Workshop
author: AWS Security Team
notes: Interactive workshop covering AWS security best practices

name: Acuart
author: Acunetix
notes: Art shopping

name: Altoro Mutual (AltoroJ)
author: IBM/Watchfire
notes: Log in with jsmith/demo1234 or admin/admin

name: Azure AD CTF Challenge
author: Azure Security Team
notes: Capture-the-flag challenges for Azure AD

name: Azure AD Pentest Lab
author: Azure Security Team
notes: Hands-on lab for Azure AD pentesting

name: Azure Infrastructure Workshop
author: Azure Security Team
notes: Interactive workshop covering Azure security best practices

name: BugBait - Vulnerable Web Application
author: Blacklock Security
notes: bugbait.io is a vulnerable web application for students, developers, cyber enthusiasts and pen testers to identify and exploit the vulnerabilities.

name: Butterfly Security Project
notes: Last updated in 2008

name: BugGPT
author: attacker-codeninja
notes: BugGPT is an intentionally vulnerable application generator for educational security training purposes.

name: CI/CD Goat
author: Cider
notes: Deliberately vulnerable CI/CD environment. Hack CI/CD pipelines, capture the flags.

name: Cyber Scavenger Hunt
author: Arthur Kay
notes: A simple scavenger hunt to learn about pentesting a website or web application.

name: DIVA Android
author: Payatu
notes: DIVA (Damn Insecure and Vulnerable App) is an intentionally vulnerable Android application designed to help security professionals and developers learn about Android security vulnerabilities.

name: DIWA - Deliberately Insecure Web Application
author: Tim Steufmehl
notes: A Deliberately Insecure Web Application

name: Damn Vulnerable Application Scanner (DVAS)
author: Andrea Valenza, Enrico Russo, Gabriele Costa
notes: An intentionally vulnerable web application scanner

name: Damn Vulnerable Bank
author: Rewanth Tammana, Akshansh Jaiswal, Hrushikesh Kakade

name: Damn Vulnerable Electron App (DVEA)
author: Najam Ul Saqib (cybersoldier)
notes: A deliberately insecure ElectronJS application

name: Damn Vulnerable Functions as a Service (DVFaaS)
author: we45 (Abhay Bhargav)

name: Damn Vulnerable Infrastructure (DVI)
author: Lorenzo Bartolini, Gabriele Costa
notes: A fully simulated and self-hosted Damn Vulnerable Infrastructure with routers, subnetworks, Scada and many other vulnerable containers. It simulates an Energy Management System inside a University Campus.

name: Damn Vulnerable NodeJS Application - DVNA
author: @appsecco
notes: Different project from the old DVNA

name: Damn Vulnerable OAuth 2.0 Applications
author: Koen Buyens
notes: A set of vulnerable applications which show Oauth2.0 vulnerabilities.

name: Damn Vulnerable Python Web Application - DVPWA
author: Oleksandr Kovalchuk

name: Damn Vulnerable Restaurant
author: theowni
notes: Damn Vulnerable Restaurant is an intentionally vulnerable Web API game for learning and training purposes dedicated to developers, ethical hackers and security engineers.

name: Defend the Web
author: Luke [flabbyrabbit]
notes: Formerly HackThis

name: Duck Store
author: DonAsako
notes: Duck Store is an intentionally vulnerable web app for training purposes on how to find classic and business logic vulns dedicated to developers, ethical hackers, and security engineers.

name: EKS Goat
author: OWASP
notes: AWS EKS Security Lab and activity.

name: FFUF.me
author: adamtlangley
notes: Target practice for ffuf

name: GCP Infrastructure CTF
author: GCP Security Team
notes: Capture-the-flag challenges for Google Cloud Platform

name: GCP Infrastructure Pentest Lab
author: GCP Security Team
notes: Hands-on lab for GCP infrastructure pentesting

name: GCP Security Workshop
author: GCP Security Team
notes: Interactive workshop covering GCP security best practices

name: Game of Active Directory
author: Orange-Cyberdefense
notes: Requires a considerably powerful system

name: Gandalf
author: Lakera
notes: A game designed to challenge your ability to interact with large language models (LLMs) and test prompt injection skills. Your goal is to trick Gandalf into revealing the secret password.

name: Gin & Juice Shop
author: PortSwigger
notes: A hosted always-online demo app with realistic technologies.

name: Goof
author: Snyk
notes: online - via Heroku deploy

name: Hack.me
author: eLearnSecurity
notes: Beta

name: HackTheBox
author: HackTheBox
notes: Online platform featuring vulnerable machines and challenges for penetration testing practice. Includes retired machines, active challenges, and Pro Labs.

name: HackThisSite
author: HackThisSite Staff
notes: Always-on CTF challenges including Basic, Realistic, Application, Steganography, and many others.

name: Hackxor
author: albinowax
notes: First 2 levels online, rest offline. Web application hacking game via missions, based on real vulnerabilities.

name: Hammer
author: iknowjason
notes: Includes manual build and docker options.

name: InjuredAndroid
author: B3nac
notes: A vulnerable Android application with CTF-style challenges focused on Android security.

name: InsecureBankv2
author: Dinesh Shetty
notes: Vulnerable Android application for security enthusiasts and developers to learn about Android insecurities. Showcases various security vulnerabilities in Android banking applications.

name: Kubernetes CTF Challenge
author: Kubernetes Security Team
notes: Capture-the-flag challenges for Kubernetes

name: Kubernetes Infrastructure Pentest Lab
author: Kubernetes Security Team
notes: Hands-on lab for Kubernetes infrastructure pentesting

name: Kubernetes Security Workshop
author: Kubernetes Security Team
notes: Interactive workshop covering Kubernetes security best practices

name: Log4Shell sample vulnerable application
author: Christophe Tafani-Dereeper, Gerard Arall, rayhan0x01 Rayhan Ahmed

name: Marathon
author: Christian Schneider
notes: Vulnerable demo application

name: OSTE-Vulnerable-Web-Application
author: (OSTE)Oudjani seyyid taqi eddine
notes: Vulnerable web application

name: OWASP SKF Labs
author: glenn.ten.cate@owasp.org and riccardo.ten.cate@owasp.org
notes: You can go to the demo website and login(admin / test-skf) or skip login, go to Labs menu and start a Lab you want to do. Please limit the usage of scanning tools on the Labs.

name: Pentest-Ground
author: Pentest-Tools.com
notes: Suite of vulnerable web apps to practice

name: Root Me
author: Root-Me
notes: Root-Me is a non-profit organization aimed at providing an outstanding learning platform for ethical hacking. It offers hundreds of challenges and virtual environments.

name: SQL injection test environment
notes: SQLmap Project

name: SecDevLabs
author: Globo
notes: Repository with many intentionally vulnerable web applications. Includes attack narratives and docker options for each app.

name: Security Tweets
author: Acunetix
notes: HTML5

name: Solyd - Introduo ao Hacking e Pentest
author: Solyd
notes: In Portuguese (Portugus) - Free online trainning with free online lab

name: UnSAFE Bank
author: lucideus
notes: Web, Android and iOS application

name: Varnish HTTP/2 Request Smuggling
author: Detectify
notes: A docker-compose file to setup a local environment that is vulnerable to CVE-2021-36740 Varnish HTTP/2 request smuggling, presented by Albinowax at Blackhat/Defcon 2021.

author: Al-Amir Badmus
name: Vuln-Bank
notes: A deliberately vulnerable banking application designed for practicing Security Testing of Web App, APIs, AI integrated App and secure code reviews. Features common vulnerabilities found in real-world applications, making it an ideal platform for security professionals, developers, and enthusiasts to learn security testing and secure coding practices in a safe environment.

name: VulnLab
author: Yavuzlar (siberyavuzlar.com)
notes: A web vulnerability lab project developed by Yavuzlar.

name: Vulnado
author: ScaleSec
notes: Purposely vulnerable Java application to help lead secure coding workshops

name: Vulnerable Node Express
author: Zachary Conger
notes: SQLi and XSS

name: VulnerableLightApp
author: Michael Vacarella
notes: Vulnerable API for educational purposes

name: VulnerableXsltConsoleApplication
author: Context Information Security
notes: This is a console app, however it relates to an issues that is relevant to web apps: use of XSLT transforms for XML files.

name: WAVSEP - Web Application Vulnerability Scanner Evaluation Project
author: Shay Chen

name: WIVET- Web Input Vector Extractor Teaser
WrongSecrets
author: Jeroen Willemsen (@commjoen), Ben de Haan (@bendehaan), Nanne Baars (@nbaars)
notes: OWASP WrongSecrets is a vulnerable app used to show how to not use secrets.

author: Fernando Mengali, Vagner Mengali
name: Yrprey
notes: Framework created in NextJs (TypeScript) and PHP/MySQL with OWASP TOP 10 API vulnerabilities of 2019 and 2023. Yrprey can was created for educational purposes, contributing to the teaching and learning of those interested in Pentest (intrusion testing) and Application Security (Appsec).

author: Fernando Mengali
name: YrpreyBlog
notes: A framework created in PHP/MySQL with OWASP TOP 10 Web Application vulnerabilities.

author: Fernando Mengali
name: YrpreyC
notes: YrpreyC is a framework written in the C language that contains vulnerabilities related to memory issues, categorized as overflows

author: Fernando Mengali
name: YrpreyC++
notes: YrpreyC++ is a framework written in the C++ language that contains vulnerabilities related to memory issues, categorized as overflows

author: Fernando Mengali
name: YrpreyPHP
notes: A framework created in PHP/MySQL with OWASP TOP 10 Web Application vulnerabilities. YrpreyPHP was created for educational purposes, contributing to the teaching and learning of those interested in Pentest (intrusion testing) and Application Security (AppSec).

author: Fernando Mengali
name: YrpreyPathTraversal
notes: YrpreyPathTraversal is a framework written in PHP, with examples of exploiting Path Traversal and Local File Inclusion vulnerabilities in different ways.

name: Zero Bank
author: Micro Focus Fortify (was HP/SpiDynamics)
notes: (username/password)

name: Zero Health
notes: Zero trust. Zero security. Total exposure. A deliberately vulnerable health tech platform with AI Chatbot for learning about application security and ethical hacking. It contains vulnerabilities from OWASP top 10 Web, API and AI/LLM Security Vulnerabilities. Highly vulnerable, never use in production.
author: Aliyu G. Yisa

name: crAPI
author: OWASP
notes: OWASP crAPI (Completely Ridiculous API) is an intentionally vulnerable API designed to help security teams practice API security testing including BOLA, BFLA, mass assignment, and authentication flaws.

name: gRPC Goat
author: rootxjs
notes: Vulnerable by Design lab for learning and practicing gRPC security.

name: insecure-deserialisation-net-poc
author: Omer Levi Hevroni
notes: A small webserver vulnerable to insecure deserialization

name: jwtdemo
author: Sjoerd Langkemper (Sjord)
notes: Practice hacking JWT tokens.

name: vAPI
author: Tushar Kulkarni
notes: vAPI is a Vulnerable Interface that demonstrates the OWASP API Top 10 vulnerabilities in the means of exercises

name: vuln-node.js-express.js-app
author: SirAppSec
notes: A Very Vulnerable Node.js Express.js Web Application and API. Used for testing Security tools, Application security and penetration testing. Using Swagger, Sqlite, Sequelize.

name: websheep
author: Younes Jaaidi (yjaaidi)
notes: Websheep is an app based on a willingly vulnerable ReSTful APIs.

author: Fernando Mengali
name: ypreyAPINodeJS
notes: yrpreyAPINodeJS is a vulnerable framework written in NodeJS and based on the OWASP TOP 10 API.

author: Fernando Mengali
name: ypreyAPIPython
notes: ypreyAPIPython is a vulnerable framework written in Python and based on the OWASP TOP 10 API.

author: Fernando Mengali
name: ypreyPollsPHP
notes: ypreyPollsPHP is a vulnerable framework written in PHP with a polls management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyASPC
notes: yrpreyASPC is a vulnerable framework written in ASP and C with vulnerabilities based on Buffer Overflow, Command Injection, and web application vulnerabilities.

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyASPCPlus
notes: yrpreyASPCPlus is a vulnerable framework written in ASP and C++ with vulnerabilities based on Buffer Overflow, Command Injection, and web application vulnerabilities.

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyFinance
notes: yrpreyFinance is a vulnerable framework written in PHP with a financial management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyLibrary
notes: yrpreyLibrary is a vulnerable framework written in PHP, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyPollsNodeJS
notes: yrpreyPollsNodeJS is a vulnerable framework written in NodeJS with a polls management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyPollsPerl
notes: yrpreyPollsPerl is a vulnerable framework written in Perl with a polls management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyPollsPython
notes: yrpreyPollsPython is a vulnerable framework written in Python with a polls management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyTasks
notes: yrpreyTasks is a vulnerable framework written in PHP with a task management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyTasksNodeJS
notes: yrpreyTasksNodeJS is a vulnerable framework written in NodeJS with a task management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10

author: Fernando Mengali
name: yrpreyTasksPython
notes: yrpreyTasksPython is a vulnerable framework written in Python with a task management scenario, based on the OWASP TOP 10
